abstracts.cdata!:
The Kenya Urban Transport Infrastructure
            Project had an unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, negligible institutional development impact,
            and overall unsatisfactory Bank and Borrower performances.
            Some of the key lessons pointed out were: 1) It is difficult
            to detect mismanagement of funds; particularly if those
            involved are the Project Manager from government and the
            task team leader from the Bank. In addition, International
            Development Association staff are not adequately trained to
            identify the "red flags" which could indicate
            project mismanagement nor are the task teams provided with
            the time or resources to identify potential problems. 2)
            Oversight accountability: The forensic audit noted weak
            oversight by government, permitting far too much discretion
            to project management. This calls for establishing an
            effective control review process, presumably within the
            Ministry of Finance, and linking project performance to the
            performance criteria of responsible staff who should be at a
            senior level. Of equal importance, project steering
            committees must be established, empowered and given real
            accountability for overseeing the proper execution of
            projects. 3) Involvement of high-level officials: Related to
            the accountability lesson, the project's example
            demonstrates the need for oversight and discussion of
            project results to be conducted at a high level, both on the
            government and Bank side. Currently, Permanent Secretaries
            of responsible ministries and senior Bank staff should do
            regular reviews, not just of project results but of
            administrative, procurement, and financial procedures. (4)
            Participation and downward accountability and communication:
            A well developed and resourced communication strategy should
            be adopted to inform civil society of project objectives,
            intended outputs, and progress in meetings these objectives
            and outputs. In addition, the project should include
            programs to actively seek the participation of civil society
            organizations in designing and implementing the agreed
            programs  Other lessons concerned streamlining the
            procurement and financial/payment procedures, strengthening
            financial and technical audits, staffing and mainstreaming
            of activities, and institutional issues.
